importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the third week of the ongoing government shutdown, during which federal workers are facing financial hardship and widespread public concern over the lack of pay and essential services.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The prolonged government shutdown highlights systemic issues in federal funding and staffing, affecting millions of workers and sparking public concern about government functionality and economic stability.

keyTakeAways: Federal workers are experiencing severe financial hardship due to being furloughed or working without pay, with approximately 1.4 million affected.
A food bank event in Landover, Maryland, served over 370 households — significantly exceeding expectations — due to the high demand from federal employees.
The event required federal employees to show their work IDs, indicating a formal and organized effort to identify and assist those directly impacted by the shutdown.
Federal workers like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams express shock at the lack of job security and financial stability, revealing a broader crisis in public trust and workplace expectations.
Lawmakers remain divided: GOP Sen. Ron Johnson proposes paying only those working during the shutdown, while Democrats advocate for full pay for all federal workers.
The event was jointly organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries, showing the role of community and religious groups in responding to government failures.

Pamelia Carter, a long-time federal employee at the Department of Agriculture, highlights the emotional and personal impact of repeated shutdowns on those who have dedicated careers to government service.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As the government shutdown enters its third week, approximately 1.4 million federal workers are furloughed or working without pay, leading to widespread financial hardship. Federal employees such as Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams are forced to seek emergency food assistance, with a food bank event in Landover, Maryland, serving over 370 households — far exceeding expectations. The event, jointly organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries, required workers to show ID, underscoring the scale of the crisis. The political divide is evident, with GOP Senator Ron Johnson proposing partial pay for workers who continue working, while Democrats demand full payment for all federal employees. Longtime federal employee Pamelia Carter reflects on the emotional toll of repeated shutdowns, emphasizing the breakdown in public trust and job security within the federal workforce.
title: Federal workers form line down the block for food pantry as shutdown hits third-week mark
